content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. A cylindrical barrel with a diameter of <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> feet contains collected rainwater, as shown in the figure above. The water drains out through a valve (not shown) at the bottom of the barrel. The rate of change of the height <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the water in the barrel with respect to time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is modeled by <math alttext="the derivative of h, with respect to t, equals, negative one tenth, times the square root of h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><msqrt><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in feet and <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in seconds. (The volume <math alttext="V" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of a cylinder with radius <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and height <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="V equals, pi, r squared, times h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.) a) Find the rate of change of the volume of water in the barrel with respect to time when the height of the water is <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> feet. Indicate units of measure.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. A cylindrical barrel with a diameter of <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> feet contains collected rainwater, as shown in the figure above. The water drains out through a valve (not shown) at the bottom of the barrel. The rate of change of the height <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the water in the barrel with respect to time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is modeled by <math alttext="the derivative of h, with respect to t, equals, negative one tenth, times the square root of h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><msqrt><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in feet and <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in seconds. (The volume <math alttext="V" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of a cylinder with radius <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and height <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="V equals, pi, r squared, times h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.) a) Find the rate of change of the volume of water in the barrel with respect to time when the height of the water is <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> feet. Indicate units of measure.

b) When the height of the water is <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> feet, is the rate of change of the height of the water with respect to time increasing or decreasing? Explain your reasoning.

c) At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> seconds, the height of the water is <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> feet. Use separation of variables to find an expression for <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in terms of <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
